title: GenomeTrackSig
contents:
paper code


Key Ideas
We observe mutational signature activity to vary on a large scale across the genome.
Chromatin changes over the course of tumour evolution may be shared across many tumours of the same tissue type. In particular: Melanoma, CLL.
Citation
Caitlin Timmons, Quaid Morris, and Caitlin F. Harrigan, “Regional Mutational Signature Activities in Cancer Genomes,” bioRxiv [preprint], Jan. 2022, doi: 10.1101/2022.01.23.477261.

title: Oncogenic mTOR mutations are detrimental in nutrient-poor conditions
contents:
paper code


Key Ideas
Many cancers lack activating mTOR mutations, but this is not the case in Renal Clear Cell Carcinoma (RCCC)
mTOR is involved in several important pathways: including growth, and nutrient sensing
In nutrient-rich conditions (such as in hypervascular kidney tissue), disregulated mTOR may be less detrimental for survival than in nutrient-poor conditions, accounting for the enrichment mTOR mutations in RCCC.
Citation
TODO

title: Considerations for Visualizing Uncertainty
contents:
paper

Key Ideas
Displaying uncertainty when visualizing a model output increases trust in the prediction
Clinicians are a unique user group because they interpret predictions by examining raw features alongside model output
Citation
Caitlin F Harrigan*, Gabriella Morgenshtern*, Anna Goldenberg, and Fanny Chevalier. “Considerations for Visualizing Uncertainty in Clinical Machine Learning Models”. Workshop: Realizing AI in Healthcare: Challenges Appearing in the Wild, CHI 2021 Online Virtual Conference (originally Yokohama, Japan), May. 2021.
* Equal contribution

title: TrackSigFreq
description: In: Proceedings of the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, January 2020
contents:
paper code


Key Ideas
Both variant allele frequency (VAF) and mutational signatures are useful for identifying subclonal cell populations
TrackSig is easily extensible to account for VAF when detecting subclonal evolution
Citation
Caitlin F Harrigan, Yulia Rubanova, Quaid Morris, and Alina Selega. “TrackSigFreq : subclonal reconstructions based on mutation signatures and allele frequencies”. In: Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing 25 (2020), pp. 238-249.

title: TrackSig
contents:
paper code


Key Ideas
Order mutations by pseudotime: every cell contains all the mutations of its ancestors
Subclonal evolution can be observed by detecting changes in mutational processes
Citation
Yulia Rubanova, Ruian Shi, Caitlin F Harrigan, Roujia Li, Jeff Wintersinger, Nil Sahin, Amit Deshwar, and Quaid Morris. “Reconstructing evolutionary trajectories of mutation signature activities in cancer using TrackSig”. En. In: Nature Communications 11.1 (Feb. 2020). Number: 1 Publisher: Nature Publishing Group, pp. 1-12.
